title: Understand the Relation of ∆G°, ∆H°, and ∆S°
text: To find the value of ∆S°, we need to use the Gibbs free energy equation:\n∆G° $$=$$ ∆H° - T∆S°\nwhere T is the temperature in Kelvin.

title: Step 1: Rearranging the Formula
text: Rearrange the Gibbs free energy equation to solve for ∆S°.\nWhat do you get?

title: Step 2: Convert Units if Necessary
text: Check the units of ∆G° and ∆H° given. Since ∆G° is given in $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, we should convert it to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$.\n\nHow many J are in $$1$$ kJ?

title: Unit Conversion
text: Convert ∆G° and ∆H° from $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$:\n∆G° in $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ $$=$$ ∆G° in $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ × $$1000$$\n∆H° in $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ $$=$$ ∆H° in $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ × $$1000$$

title: Step 3: Perform the Calculation
text:
Substitute the given values into the rearranged equation to find ∆S°:
- ∆H° $$=$$ $$-45.90$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$, which is $$-45900$$ $$ rac{J}{mol}$$
- ∆G° $$=$$ $$-33.30$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$, which is $$-33300$$ $$ rac{J}{mol}$$
- T $$=$$ $$298$$ K

What is the value of ∆S° in $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$?
